### Literature Review: Sleep Deprivation and Cognitive Performance

Recent experimental work consistently shows that even short periods of sleep deprivation deteriorate cognitive faculties. A 24‑hour total sleep loss reduces working‑memory accuracy by roughly a quarter, while 36‑hour restriction slows reaction times by 180 ms and raises error rates by 12%. Prolonged deprivation (48 h) also dampens dorsolateral prefrontal activation by about 30%, indicating compromised neural efficiency. Collectively, these findings highlight the vulnerability of executive processes to insufficient sleep.
